info.name: Merchant Ships
info.attribution:
Original layout, coding, and asset design done by Shobu and licensed for use on VTT. Code modifications and functionality adjustments performed by Dexdouglas, with assistance from AndyPy and LawDawg, licensed for use on VTT.

Cover image created using AI https://labs.google/fx/tools/image-fx with a prompt of "Renaissance era style pencil drawing of a ship and a captain buying goods at an auction with light color at a dock"
info.description: In Merchant Ships, players are Renaissance era merchant captains competing to acquire and sell the most valuable goods, aiming for the highest profits by the end of the game.
info.ruleText:
To start the game, have all players "Click to sit" and hit the "New Game" button. The game will select a random starting player and your "Player Bank" of 50 points will remain hidden throughout the game to the other players. If playing with less than 7 players, some cards will be moved to the Discard holder. The deck of 50 cards contains cards valued 1-10 in 5 suits. On your turn, you can reveal 1, 2, or 3 cards faceup from the deck by dragging them from the deck to the 3 white holders next to the deck. After revealing a card, you can choose to start an auction by pressing the "Start Auction" button. Everyone will then secretly enter a bid amount by clicking the circle under the "Player Bid" area. A bid of 0 is valid. As bids are entered, the green check mark will be visible next to the bid area. Once all bids are in, the active player can hit the "End Auction" button and reveal all bids. A "Winner" or a "No Winner" button will be shown. The highest bidder will hit the "Winner" button which will move all the auctioned cards to their holding area and tally the value of their cards so be shown under the "Round Total". The Winner button will also reduce the players bank by the value of their bid. All other players do not spend anything, and the player indicator will move to the next player in turn order to start the next round of auctions. In the event of a tie, the person sitting closest in clockwise order from the start player, but NOT including the start player, will win the tie. If everyone bids 0 on the selection of cards, the "No Winner" button will be revealed, and the start player should hit the "No Winner" button to move the revealed cards to the discard and shift the player indicator to the next person in turn order. You cannot bid on lots if you don't have enough space for all the cards. NOTE: You can only reveal as many cards as at least one other player has room for. This means that you can reveal cards for an auction that you cannot bid on.
As you bid for cards, you are depleting your bank of points in the hopes that at the end of the game you will have made wise business decisions, and your cards will be worth more than you paid for them. NOTE: If you have filled all 6 of your available spaces, you will not be able to take any further turns for the game and your turn will be skipped. Your green check mark next to your bid will remain green for the rest of the game. If you have at least 1 open space, you can still reveal cards. NOTE: If you are the last player with open spaces, you will drag cards from the top of the deck to your open spaces for free until you have completely filled your empty spaces. GAME END The game ends as soon as all players have filled their ships. The game will also end if the last of the cards are auctioned and the deck is empty. The player with the highest total receives the most points for their cards. The next player receives fewer points and so on. The table at the bottom left of the screen details the points dispensed. In the event of a tie, the tied players add all the values between them and divide equally, rounding down. Example: in a 5-player game, player A has the highest Round Total of 35 and earns 40 points, Player B and C both have the next highest Round Total with 27 and must sum the 2nd and 3rd place points (30+20) and divide them equally amongst the 2 of them (25 points each). Player D had the 3rd highest Round Total with 26 but they only receive 10 points. Player E receives nothing as they were the 5th highest Round Total and 5th place receives nothing in a 5-player game. Variants: Color bonus: As an added method of scoring points, you can award an additional 10-point bonus at the end of the game if someone has managed to acquire 5 different colors of cards to their area. Live Auction: Another variant is to allow all players to bid aloud, like a live auction, with the start player announcing "going once, going twice, sold" once the bids start to slow down. The starting player can of course still bid in this fashion, but they need to allow others time to speak after their bid and before closing the auction. Multiple games: You can choose to play several games in a row but allowing the scores to carry over between games. Do not reveal your scores at the end of each game and only reveal after the agreed upon # of rounds are complete.

fields.text: Not all players have indicated they are ready. Are you sure you want to end the auction?

sp70.text: You earn an additional 10 point bonus if all 5 colors are represented on your boat

sp71.text: Open Auction: Instead of a blind bid, try a live auction with everyone bidding freely. Once the bids slow down, the start player should announce: Going once, going twice, sold.

thenRoutine: // This just makes sure some cards are dealt so long as at least one seat is occupied. Useful for testing and messing around.

fields.text: This will update scores, move the auction cards, and change the turn. Only the auction winner should press this button. Are you sure?
If nobody won the auction, this will discard the auction cards, and change the turn. Is that ok?
